leadAgency: Alabama Department of Economic and Community Affairs (ADECA)
notes: Alabama received $203.4M for FY2026. ADECA developing rules to help healthcare providers and eligible recipients 'apply and compete' for funding under 11 ARHTP initiatives. Per Feb 5, 2026 Alabama Reflector report, ADECA director briefed lawmakers on funding distribution across 11 initiatives. Once a consultant is selected, hospitals can apply for funds directed to them aligned with the initiatives. Entity-level funding expected to be distributed toward end of FY2026 (by Sept 30, 2026). Governor Ivey will issue executive order in early 2026 creating advisory group. Alabama Legislature expected to consider implementation legislation during 2026 session (typically Feb-May). No vendor RFA/RFP posted yet.
programAddress: Alabama Department of Economic and Community Affairs (ADECA), P.O. Box 5690, Montgomery, AL 36103-5690

leadAgency: Alaska Department of Health
notes: Alaska received $272.2M/year for 5 years. LOI REGISTRATION NOW OPEN: Letter of Interest portal opens February 17, 2026 and closes March 11, 2026. Office Hours webinars: Feb 17, Feb 24, March 3 (noon-1 PM). Alaska Community Foundation (ACF) is subrecipient administrator managing applications and fund distribution. Four funding pathways: (1) Administrative readiness grants, (2) Planning grants (expected April), (3) Project implementation grants (expected May), (4) Targeted innovation prepackaged projects. All applications require Unique Entity ID (UEI) via Sam.gov. Broad eligibility: Alaska providers, clinics, hospitals, non-profits, community organizations, tribal organizations. Sustainability plan required with all applications. DOH capped administrative spending at 10%. Multiple application windows tied to federal budget periods. Contact: RHTP@alaska.gov. Updates signup: public.govdelivery.com/accounts/AKDHSS/signup/48430.
programAddress: Alaska Department of Health, 3601 C Street, Suite 902, Anchorage, AK 99503

leadAgency: Arizona Center for Rural Health / AHCCCS / ADHS
notes: Arizona received $167.0M for FY2026. Revised budget submitted to CMS Jan 30, 2026; CMS has 30-day review period (approval expected end of Feb/early March 2026). Arizona received $33M less than expected, requiring budget revisions. State toolkit page confirms NOFOs/RFPs likely starting March/April 2026 after CMS budget approval. AHCCCS is designated lead for administering/distributing funds. Four priority areas: Rural Health Education & Training (25%), Behavioral/Maternal/Chronic Disease (15%), Telehealth/Innovation (22%), Medical Equipment & Technology (23%). Lead agencies: Office of Economic Opportunity, AHCCCS, ADHS. Dr. Derksen presentation updated 2/4/2026 available on toolkit page. Arizona Center for Rural Health offers letters of support via online form. AHCCCS has dedicated RHTP page at azahcccs.gov. Monitor program toolkit page for NOFO release.
programAddress: Arizona Center for Rural Health, 1295 N. Martin Ave., P.O. Box 245163, Tucson, AZ 85724

leadAgency: Office of Governor Sarah Huckabee Sanders
notes: Arkansas received $208.8M for FY2026 ($209M rounded). Governor's office and DFA led the application. Four initiatives: RISE AR (workforce/residencies), THRIVE (AI/telehealth/coordinated records), HEART (preventive care/health outcomes), PACT (specialty care/screenings/trauma services). First disbursement of funding to the state expected early 2026. No downstream RFA, RFP, or subgrant application has been posted yet. ACHI (Arkansas Center for Health Improvement) published program overview at achi.net/publications/overview-of-the-rural-health-transformation-program-in-arkansas/.
programAddress: Office of Governor Sarah Huckabee Sanders, State Capitol, Suite 250, 500 Woodlane Street, Little Rock, AR 72201

leadAgency: California Department of Health Care Access and Information (HCAI)
notes: California received $233.6M for FY2026. HCAI/CalSORH is the lead. Still in planning phase - application narratives under CMS review and subject to change pending final CMS award decisions. Updated budget narrative posted January 2026. Three overarching initiative areas: Transformative Care Model, Workforce Development, Technology. Kickoff webinar (Sept 4, 2025) and five listening sessions (Oct 1-3, 2025) recordings available. Stakeholders encouraged to join Rural Health email listserv for updates on webinars, surveys, and engagement opportunities. Contact: CalSORH@hcai.ca.gov or CalRHT@hcai.ca.gov. RHTP Program Overview, Project Narrative, Budget Narrative, and Project Abstract available on program page.
programAddress: Department of Health Care Access and Information (HCAI), 2020 West El Camino Avenue, Suite 800, Sacramento, CA 95833

leadAgency: Colorado Department of Health Care Policy and Financing (HCPF)
notes: Colorado received $200.1M for FY2026. HCPF is actively developing RFA materials. RHTP Advisory Committee applications closed February 16, 2026. Advisory Committee will advise HCPF on application process, funding priorities, and public-facing materials. First committee meeting: March 2026. Application scoring/evaluation will be conducted by external vendor overseen by HCPF. Advisory Committee overview memo available on program page. RFA cannot be finalized until cooperative agreement with CMS is complete. 10 initiatives that providers/nonprofits can submit proposals to fulfill. Eligible providers in 52 rural/frontier Colorado counties should monitor for RFA release. Newsletters issued Jan 5 and Jan 12, 2026. Webinar recordings available (English, Spanish, ASL) from December 2, 2025 presentation. Contact: hcpf_RHTP@state.co.us.
programAddress: Department of Health Care Policy and Financing (HCPF), 303 E. 17th Avenue, Suite 1100, Denver, CO 80203

leadAgency: Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS)
notes: Connecticut received $154.2M for FY2026. State has NOT received CMS authorization to distribute funds - subject to additional negotiation and review. DSS has hired/is hiring three positions for RHTP implementation: Assistant Director of Rural Health Transformation (under DSS, posting closed Jan 6, 2026), and two Health Information Technology Durational Project Managers (under Office of Health Strategy, funded through Feb 2030). Documents page has Governor's endorsement letter, project narrative, and budget narrative. Public comment page available. 31 different initiatives including mobile medical/dental vans and expanded telehealth. When vendor applications are released, they will appear on both DSS RHTP page and CT state procurement website. Monitor both regularly.
programAddress: Connecticut Department of Social Services, 55 Farmington Avenue, Hartford, CT 06105

leadAgency: Delaware Department of Health and Social Services / Division of Public Health
notes: Delaware received $157.4M for FY2026. SIX RFPs NOW OPEN on Delaware's procurement portal (mmp.delaware.gov). Active RFPs posted Feb 6-12, 2026: (1) Medical School Partnership (HSS26061-MEDSCHPSHP) - $42.5M, deadline March 27, 2026; (2) Food Is Medicine Infrastructure Initiative (HSS26060-FIMII) - $1.65M, deadline April 10, 2026; (3) Rural Community Health Hubs (HSS26062-RURALCHHUB) - $5.48M, deadline April 17, 2026; (4) School-Based Health Centers Expansion (HSS26064-SBHCEI) - $195K, deadline April 10, 2026; (5) Healthy Living in Rural Delaware Diabetes Wellness Program (HSS26063-HLIRDDWP) - $950K, deadline April 16, 2026; (6) Rural Library-Based Health Access (HSS26065-RLIBBASHLT) - $1.84M, deadline April 15, 2026. Additional RFPs expected spring 2026 for: Hope Centers ($26.4M), Telehealth & RPM ($5M), Workforce Data Technology ($2.7M), Value-Based Care Transformation ($24.3M), Prior Authorization Network ($6.4M), and others. DPH now has dedicated RHTP page. Contact: ricky.williamson@delaware.gov or dhssinfo@delaware.gov.
programAddress: Office of Governor Matt Meyer, 150 Martin Luther King Jr Blvd South, Dover, DE 19901

leadAgency: Florida Agency for Health Care Administration (AHCA)
notes: Florida received $209.9M for FY2026. AHCA plans to release an RFA where regional collaboratives (groups of rural and other providers) will submit grant proposals. However, AHCA must first receive legislative appropriation before spending funds - this is a prerequisite blocking RFA release. No RHTP-related solicitations on AHCA procurements page or MyFloridaMarketPlace yet. Feb 18, 2026 webinar (1-2 PM EST) on program structure, timelines, and expectations - register via Teams event link on program page. AHCA FAQ updated Feb 2, 2026. Presentation slides and regional map available. 15 key initiatives spanning: access to care, behavioral health, telehealth, tele-ICU, workforce development, payment reform, RPM, nutrition/SDOH. Monitor: ahca.myflorida.com/procurements and MyFloridaMarketPlace VIP portal. Contact: RHTP@ahca.myflorida.com.
programAddress: Agency for Health Care Administration (AHCA), 2727 Mahan Drive, Tallahassee, FL 32308

leadAgency: Georgia Department of Community Health (DCH)
notes: Georgia received $218.9M for FY2026 under 'GREAT Health' program. DCH received final CMS approval for amended Year 1 budget. DCH setting up competitive grant process where eligible providers must apply and show projects 'cannot maintain the status quo.' Funds must be allocated by October 2026, creating urgency. Largest single allocation: $56.7M for providers transitioning to AHEAD model. Per Feb 9, 2026 GPB report, hospitals are aligning proposals with GREAT plan priorities (telehealth, emergency preparedness, workforce development). DCH Grant Announcements page shows RFGA Dual Track FY26 - Rural Hospital Support Grant (posted Jan 20, 2026) for Hospital Stabilization or Graduate Medical Education with Q&A posted Feb 6. 29 separate projects across five major categories. Register for grant announcements with DCH at grants@dch.ga.gov. Contact: GREATHealth@dch.ga.gov.
programAddress: Georgia Department of Community Health, 2 Martin Luther King Jr. Drive SE, East Tower, Atlanta, GA 30334

leadAgency: Executive Office of the State of Hawaii
notes: Hawaii received $188.9M for FY2026 (one of highest per-capita amounts). State finalizing cooperative agreement with CMS - must be completed before releasing funds. Six initiatives: Rural Health Information Network (RHIN), Pili Ola Telehealth Network, Rural Infrastructure for Care Access (RICA), HOME RUN Rural Healthcare Workforce Pipeline, Rural Respite Network, Rural Value-Based Innovation and AHEAD Readiness Fund. State will finalize updated budget based on $188.9M award following CMS negotiations, then begin releasing funds to lead agencies and partners. All procurements must follow state procurement laws; solicitations will appear on HIePRO (hiepro.ehawaii.gov) and HANDS (hands.ehawaii.gov/hands/opportunities). No RHTP-specific procurements on HIePRO or SPO RFP page yet. Monitor: HIePRO and SPO Request for Proposals page (spo.hawaii.gov).
programAddress: Executive Chambers, State Capitol, 415 South Beretania Street, Honolulu, HI 96813

leadAgency: Idaho Department of Health and Welfare (DHW)
notes: Idaho received $186.0M annually for five years (~$930M total). Funding will be subawarded in accordance with Idaho procurement law. Plans include telehealth expansion, workforce recruitment/training, disease prevention, and 3.5% set-aside for tribal health care programs. No RFP or procurement posted on Idaho Division of Purchasing website or DHW program page. Monitor: purchasing.idaho.gov. Contact: IdahoRHTP@dhw.idaho.gov.
programAddress: Idaho Department of Health and Welfare, 450 West State Street, 4th Floor, Boise, ID 83720

leadAgency: Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services (HFS)
notes: Illinois received $193.4M for FY2026. HFS applied for $1B total ($200M/year over 5 years). Three initiative categories: Transforming Rural Healthcare, Overcoming Geographic Barriers to Care, Building a Resilient Rural Workforce. No downstream subgrant or vendor opportunities posted yet.
programAddress: Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services, 201 South Grand Avenue East, Springfield, IL 62763

leadAgency: Indiana Family and Social Services Administration (FSSA) / Indiana Department of Health
notes: Indiana received $206.9M for FY2026. GROW regional grant application framework published with detailed timeline. $600M over 5 years across 8 regional coalitions ($120M annually). RFA releases March 1, 2026 with technical assistance beginning same day. TA period: March-July 2026. Applications due July 1, 2026 (no late submissions). Review/scoring: July-September 2026. Award announcements: no later than September 1, 2026. Grant period begins October 1, 2026. MUST apply as regional coalition - individual applications NOT accepted. Priority: 64 HRSA-designated rural counties + 9 partially-rural counties. Capital costs capped at 20%, EMR at 5%. 11-member Regional Committees per region expected to be announced February 2026. Presentation PDFs available on regional grants sub-page. State-managed application portal available by March 1. Regional Grants page: in.gov/grow-rural-health/regional-grants/. Contact: GrowRuralHealth@health.in.gov.
programAddress: Indiana Family and Social Services Administration, 402 West Washington Street, Indianapolis, IN 46204

leadAgency: Iowa Department of Health and Human Services
notes: Iowa received $209.0M for FY2026. FIRST STATE IN THE NATION to award RHTP vendor funding. On Jan 30, 2026, Governor Reynolds announced $78.6M+ in competitive RFP awards. Seven RFPs now in post-award phase with Notices of Intent to Award posted: (1) RFP PHTHORC26009 - Best and Brightest Medical Equipment ($66M), NOIA 1/30-2/13; (2) RFP PHTHORC26010 - Best and Brightest Rural Healthcare Workforce ($12.6M, up to $120K/provider), NOIA 1/30-2/13; (3) RFP PHTHORC26008 - Centers of Excellence, NOIA 2/5-2/12; (4) RFP PHTHOCC26755 - Combat Cancer Prevention and Screening, NOIA 2/5-2/12; (5) RFP COMPADM26001 - Combat Cancer Technical Assistance Provider, NOIA 2/5-2/12; (6) RFP COMPADM26002 - Health Hub Technical Assistance Provider, awarded ~Feb 2; (7) RFP COMPADM26003 - Communities of Care Technical Assistance Provider, NOIA 2/5-2/12. All seven RFPs now closed. Additional RFPs for other Healthy Hometowns initiatives expected. Health Hub Awardees anticipated to start Oct 1, 2026. Contact: healthyhometowns@hhs.iowa.gov or John McMullen (515) 416-8565.
programAddress: Iowa Department of Health and Human Services, Lucas Building, 321 East 12th Street, Des Moines, IA 50319

leadAgency: Kansas Department of Health and Environment (KDHE)
notes: Kansas received $221.9M for FY2026. KDHE led the application with stakeholder and community engagement. No downstream RFA, RFP, or subgrant application has been posted yet.
programAddress: Kansas Department of Health and Environment, 1000 SW Jackson Street, Suite 540, Topeka, KS 66612

leadAgency: Kentucky Cabinet for Health and Family Services (CHFS) / Dept for Public Health
notes: Kentucky received $212.9M for FY2026 under 'Team Kentucky Rural Health Transformation.' Five interrelated initiatives planned. Regional funds will be awarded via competitive RFA with committee scoring/oversight. Led by RHTP Grant Director within HFS with Executive Oversight and State Steering Committees. Key initiatives include: 24/7 Medical Operations Coordination Center, EMR referral module connecting ~450 rural entities to HIE, 'Rooted in Health' Rural Dental Access Program. Monitor: ruralhealthplan.ky.gov and finance.ky.gov/eProcurement.
programAddress: Cabinet for Health and Family Services, 275 East Main Street, Frankfort, KY 40621

leadAgency: Louisiana Department of Health (LDH)
notes: Louisiana received $208.4M for FY2026 (among highest nationally, top 3 in Southeast). Julie Foster Hagan named Executive Director for RHTP. January 2026 notification target has been missed - no funding opportunity notifications posted as of Feb 14, 2026. LDH program page lists eligible rural health facility types (rural health clinics, FQHCs, community mental health centers, opioid treatment programs, CCBHCs, Critical Access Hospitals, Sole Community Hospitals, Medicare-dependent, Low-volume, Rural Emergency Hospitals). Focus areas: chronic/complex conditions, behavioral health, perinatal/postpartum, cancer disparities, workforce, infrastructure (telehealth, EHR), paramedicine, medically tailored meal programs. Nearly 1.1M rural residents targeted; 37% on Medicaid. Funds must be obligated by end of FY following allocation. Contact: RHTP@la.gov.
programName: Rural Health Transformation and Sustainability Program
programAddress: Louisiana Department of Health, 628 N. 4th Street, Baton Rouge, LA 70802

leadAgency: Maine Department of Health and Human Services
notes: Maine received $190.0M for FY2026. No downstream RFA, RFP, or subgrant application has been posted yet.
programAddress: Maine Department of Health and Human Services, 109 Capitol Street, 11 State House Station, Augusta, ME 04333

leadAgency: Maryland Department of Health
notes: Maryland received $168.2M for FY2026. Program page explicitly states upcoming 'opportunities to apply for the RHTP Committee and to submit proposals for competitive subrecipient funding.' Currently in discussion with CMS regarding approved programs and adjusted budget details. Two funding categories planned: (1) Immediate Impact Funds for shovel-ready activities, (2) Transformation Funds for longer-term competitive initiatives. Three major initiatives: Transform Rural Health Workforce, Promote Sustainable Access and Innovative Care, Empower Rural Marylanders to Eat for Health. Sept 2025 RFI received 325+ responses. Known subrecipients include state agencies (Agriculture, Emergency Management, Labor, Housing), Rural Maryland Council, CRISP, local health departments, local EMS, and Maryland AHEC. MDH establishing RHT Committee. Contact: mdh.transformruralhealth@maryland.gov.
programAddress: Maryland Department of Health, 201 W. Preston Street, Baltimore, MD 21201

leadAgency: Massachusetts Executive Office of Health and Human Services (EOHHS)
notes: Massachusetts received $162.0M for FY2026. Application discusses rural health needs, facility viability, proposed initiatives, metrics/evaluation, sustainability plan. No downstream RFA, RFP, or subgrant application has been posted yet.
programAddress: Executive Office of Health and Human Services, One Ashburton Place, 11th Floor, Boston, MA 02108

leadAgency: Michigan Department of Health and Human Services (MDHHS)
notes: Michigan received $173.1M for FY2026 (CMS approved all activities at reduced scale). MDHHS launched RHTP Listserv for program updates - subscribers will be first to know when GFO (Grant Funding Opportunity), application materials, and technical assistance resources become available. Subscribe at MDHHS-RHTP@michigan.gov. Seeking applicants for Rural Health Transformation Advisory Council (announced Jan 13, 2026) - advisory role, not funding. MDHHS will administer a series of grant programs; grants available once MDHHS receives final budget approval from CMS. MHA released RHTP FAQ document (Feb 2026). Three priorities: Make Rural America Healthy Again, Sustainable Access, Workforce Development. Contact: MDHHS-RHTP@michigan.gov.
programAddress: Michigan Department of Health and Human Services, 333 S. Grand Ave, P.O. Box 30195, Lansing, MI 48909

leadAgency: Minnesota Department of Health
notes: Minnesota received $193.1M for FY2026. Grants page: health.state.mn.us/facilities/ruralhealth/ruraltrans/grants.html. Organizations may apply for funding through an allocation and/or through a competitive process, depending on eligibility. Funding for rural health organizations will be released in 2026. Implementation engagement began early 2026. FAQ document available at health.state.mn.us/facilities/ruralhealth/ruraltrans/docs/rhtpfaq.pdf. Contact: rural.transformation.mdh@state.mn.us.
programAddress: Minnesota Department of Health, Office of Rural Health and Primary Care, P.O. Box 64975, St. Paul, MN 55164-0975

leadAgency: Mississippi State Department of Health
notes: Mississippi received $205.9M for FY2026. Legislature pushing HB1067 requiring competitive bidding for all RHTP vendors/subcontractors (engrossed Feb 4, referred to Senate Public Health & Welfare Committee Feb 13). Bill would require competitive bid process for vendors providing goods/services, including statewide health needs assessment, medical equipment, workforce programming, and health information system design. Would prioritize subgrantees in rural areas. Governor's office overseeing fund distribution. RFQ posted (RFx# 3120003272) for accounting, auditing, and third-party administration consulting services for RHTP oversight/compliance. Six initiatives planned. No provider RFA/RFP posted yet.
programAddress: Mississippi Division of Medicaid, 550 High Street, Suite 1000, Jackson, MS 39201

leadAgency: Missouri Department of Social Services
notes: Missouri received $216.3M for FY2026 (9th largest). Detailed procurement roadmap published on dedicated Rural Health page. Upcoming opportunities: Social Care Referral Platform/CIE RFI (Q1 2026), Ambient AI RFI (Q1 2026), Remote Patient Technology feedback (Q2 2026), Social Care Referral Platform/CIE RFP (Q3 2026). Q1 2026 RFIs have not yet been posted - potentially overdue. Program envisions 7 regional coordinating networks and up to 30 community hubs (2-5 counties each). Plans to hire 100+ people (90 for hubs, 20-25 for regional networks). Largest budget item: 'digital backbone' for data sharing ($364M over 5 years). Also plans 10 hospital infrastructure grants and 3 new service grants (oncology/obstetric surgery) in 2026. Tech contracts and staffing for new Rural Health Transformation Office also on 2026 agenda. MHA, Missouri Behavioral Health Council, and Missouri Primary Care Association are tier-one stakeholders. ToRCH FAQs page: mydss.mo.gov/torch-faqs. Monitor mydss.mo.gov/mhd/rural-health for new opportunities.
programName: ToRCH Care (Transformation of Rural Community Health Care)
programAddress: Missouri Department of Social Services, MO HealthNet Division, 615 Howerton Court, P.O. Box 6500, Jefferson City, MO 65102-6500

leadAgency: Montana Department of Public Health and Human Services (DPHHS)
notes: Montana received $233.5M for FY2026 (4th highest, up to $1.2B over 5 years). First Stakeholder Advisory Committee meeting held Jan 22, 2026 at MSU with 600+ participants (in-person and virtual). Revised budget submitted Jan 30; CMS has 30-day review - initial funding expected no later than March 1, 2026. Procurement timeline: Jan-March 2026 anticipated RFP/procurement process for DPHHS to select partner(s) for program facilitation and fund distribution; April-June 2026 anticipated partner contract award decisions and funding distribution begins. Most initiatives via competitive bidding at bids.mt.gov; some via government-to-government contracts or grant applications. Direct funding announcements at ruralhealth.mt.gov. State will prefer smaller number of statewide partners rather than individual providers. Five core initiatives: Workforce, Sustainable Access, Innovative Care, Community Health & Prevention, Technology Innovation. Eligible: tribal nations, government agencies, health care providers, educational institutions, nonprofits. MHA partner interest form available. Contact: HHSRuralHealthTransformation@mt.gov.
programAddress: Montana Department of Public Health and Human Services, P.O. Box 4210, Helena, MT 59604-4210

leadAgency: Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services
notes: Nebraska received $218.5M for FY2026. State intends to release multiple RFAs for organizations to apply for funds across seven integrated initiatives: (1) Food as Medicine (school kitchen modernization, food pantries, farm-to-school), (2) Regionalized Rural Access and Navigation, (3) Rural Workforce Acceleration, (4) eHealth and Mobile Care, (5) Rural Emergency Behavioral Health, (6) Assisted Living Facility Special Needs Population Incentive, (7) Rural Health Technology Catalyst Fund. Revised budgets submitted to CMS by Jan 30, 2026 with 30-day review period - March 2026 earliest for RFAs. GovDelivery notification signup available: public.govdelivery.com/accounts/NESTATE/subscriber/new?topic_id=NESTATE_834. Nebraska Initiatives Overview PDF available on program page. Monitor dedicated RHTP page and DHHS Contract Opportunities page. Contact: DHHS.RHTP@nebraska.gov.
programAddress: Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services, 301 Centennial Mall South, Lincoln, NE 68508

leadAgency: Nevada Health Authority
notes: Nevada received $179.9M for FY2026. Program page confirms applications and procurement requirements will be announced 'this spring and summer.' RHTSC Steering Committee application closed Jan 19, 2026; first Steering Committee meeting scheduled March 11, 2026 at 1:00 PM. Winter Stakeholder Update Workshop held Jan 27, 2026. ATI Advisory reports RHIT Grant RFP will be released May 2026, with awards in September 2026 (contracts Sept 15, 2026 - Sept 30, 2027). Four funded initiatives with allocations: RHOAP virtual specialty mentorship/RPM/AI (15%, ~$27M/yr), Flex Fund for rural provider infrastructure (20%, ~$36M/yr), Workforce Recruitment and Rural Access (40%, ~$72M/yr), Rural Health Innovation and Technology Grant (15%, ~$27M/yr). Strong preference for awards to rural CAHs, CCBHCs, clinics, FQHCs, school-based health centers. Sign up for NVHA ListServ for announcements. Contact: RHTP@nvha.nv.gov.
programAddress: Nevada Health Authority, 9850 Double R Blvd, Reno, NV 89521

leadAgency: New Hampshire Department of Health and Human Services
notes: New Hampshire received $204.0M for FY2026, the largest award among New England states. Governor Ayotte established GO-NORTH (Governor's Office of New Opportunities & Rural Transformational Health) to oversee implementation. Donnalee Lozeau (former Nashua mayor) appointed Director in Jan 2026. GO-NORTH is an independent office within DHHS. Governor stated GO-NORTH will issue 'a series of requests for proposals' in 'coming weeks' to solicit applications on how to spend RHTP dollars. 'Granite Strong. Future Ready.' plan focuses on preventive health, sustainable access, workforce, innovative payment models, technology/digital health. Over 300 stakeholders contributed input. Initial investments expected to support rural providers beginning in 2026. Monitor: dhhs.nh.gov RHTP page and Open RFPs page. Contact: RHTF@dhhs.nh.gov.
programAddress: New Hampshire Department of Health and Human Services, 129 Pleasant Street, Concord, NH 03301

leadAgency: New Jersey Department of Health
notes: New Jersey received $147.3M for FY2026 (smallest state award). RFA 'Rural Health Transformation Program-Advancing Technology, Prevention, and Workforce Capacity 2026' - application window CLOSED (opened Dec 30, 2025, closed Jan 20, 2026). Now in review/award phase. $27.5M distributed via four activity areas: Activity A - Rural Preventive Health ($8M, up to 16 awards of $200K-$800K), Activity B - Telehealth & RPM ($9M, up to 10 awards of $200K-$1M), Activity C - Training & Capacity Building ($500K, up to 3 awards of $50K-$250K), Activity D - Workforce Recruitment/Retention ($10M, single award). Project/budget period: Feb 1 - Oct 30, 2026. Vendor resource directory and technical assistance Q&A document published. Applied via NJ DOH SAGE IntelliGrants portal. RFA document: healthapps.nj.gov/noticeofgrant/documents/DOHP26RHT_rfa.pdf. Eligible: municipal/county governments, educational institutions, hospitals, nonprofits, clinics, CBOs, tribal organizations serving rural NJ. Contact: RHTP.Application@doh.nj.gov.
programName: New Jersey Rural Health Transformation Program
programAddress: New Jersey Department of Health, P.O. Box 360, Trenton, NJ 08625-0360

leadAgency: New Mexico Health Care Authority (HCA)
notes: New Mexico received $211.5M for FY2026. Guidehouse awarded consultant support contract for application preparation. Funding will be distributed through two primary mechanisms: direct subawards and competitive procurements/applications. HCA previously issued RFP 26-630-8000-0007 for consultant support (closed Sept 17, 2025) and RFI for stakeholder input (closed Oct 10, 2025) - both were pre-application, NOT downstream vendor funding. No downstream subgrant or vendor application posted yet. Monitor HCA Open RFPs page (hca.nm.gov/lookingforinformation/open-rfps/).
programName: New Mexico Rural Health Transformation Program
programAddress: New Mexico Health Care Authority, P.O. Box 2348, Santa Fe, NM 87504-2348

leadAgency: New York State Department of Health
notes: New York received $212.1M for FY2026. Four initiatives: Rural Community Health Integration, Technology-Enhanced Primary Care (PCMH with AI), Rural Roots Workforce Development, Technology Innovation/Cybersecurity. January 16, 2026 presentation available on program page. No downstream subgrant or vendor RFA posted yet. Contact: RHTP@health.ny.gov.
programName: Transforming Rural Healthcare in New York
programAddress: New York State Department of Health, Corning Tower, Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12237

leadAgency: North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (NCDHHS)
notes: North Carolina received $213.0M for FY2026. NC ROOTS (Rural Organizations Orchestrating Transformation for Sustainability) Hubs are regional, locally governed networks coordinating care across primary care, behavioral health, workforce, value-based payment, digital health. NCDHHS plans to release RFA for NC ROOTS Hub Lead organizations by March 2026, selecting six leads (one per Medicaid Standard Plan region). Hub Lead selection and onboarding: April-October 2026. Hub Leads will provide centralized governance and support for network partners including rural hospitals, FQHCs, and private physician practices. Jan 16, 2026 town hall recording available (YouTube). Jan 30 revised budget submitted to CMS. FAQ page available. Maggie Sauer (Office of Rural Health director) advises interested organizations to begin conversations with partner organizations now about collective goals as Hub Lead. Six strategic focus areas: Community-Rooted Care Networks, Prevention/Chronic Disease Management, Behavioral Health Expansion, Workforce Development, Financial Sustainability, Technology/Innovation. Contact: monitor ncdhhs.gov RHTP page.
programName: NC ROOTS (Rural Organizations Orchestrating Transformation for Sustainability)
programAddress: NC Department of Health and Human Services, 2001 Mail Service Center, Raleigh, NC 27699-2000

leadAgency: North Dakota Health and Human Services
notes: North Dakota received $198.9M for FY2026 ($500M+ over 5 years). Program page updated Feb 10, 2026. Grants page states 'Apply now' but specific RFAs not yet detailed on main page. HHS Commissioner Pat Traynor stated department plans to start rolling out grant opportunities in February and encouraged providers, faith communities, schools, and others to apply. Legislature approved $398M for first two years via special session (bills signed by Governor Armstrong). Budget: $116M access, $33.4M technology, $32.2M workforce, $17.1M healthy lifestyles. Short application turnaround expected - must commit funds by Oct 2026. Broad eligibility: providers, faith communities, schools, others. Tribal liaison being hired. GovDelivery signup: public.govdelivery.com/accounts/NDDHHS/subscriber/new?topic_id=NDDHHS_189. Contact: rhtp@nd.gov.
programName: North Dakota Rural Health Transformation Program
programAddress: North Dakota Health and Human Services, 600 East Boulevard Ave., Bismarck, ND 58505-0250

leadAgency: Ohio Department of Health
notes: Ohio received $202.0M for FY2026. Solicitation reference documents page: odh.ohio.gov/know-our-programs/rural-health-transformation-program/solicitation-reference-documents. ACTIVE VENDOR RFP: 'Rural Health Workforce Pipeline; Pathways Upskilling and Retention' (SRC0000036107). Posted Jan 2, 2026, deadline March 10, 2026 at 3:00 PM EST. Questions due Feb 27. Estimated $5M-$15M annually, up to $60M total contract value. Contract period: April 1, 2026 - June 30, 2027 with renewals through June 30, 2031. Scope: statewide workforce pipeline strategy across high schools, career tech, community colleges, universities, and employers in 73 rural counties. Includes apprenticeships, CHW and pharmacist training, recruitment incentives, 6-month housing stipends for 5-year rural service commitments. One award anticipated. Additional RFPs for other pillars (Rural Health Innovation Hubs, Emergency Care, School-Based Health Centers, OH SEE Expansion) expected - ODH website states 'watch for additional RFPs.' Pharmacy services grants also open alongside worker training. Submit via OhioBuys.
programAddress: Ohio Department of Health, 246 N. High Street, Columbus, OH 43215

leadAgency: Oklahoma State Department of Health
notes: Oklahoma received $223.5M for FY2026 (one of highest allocations). CMS has now released ~$202M of the $223.5M award, with $21M remaining under review. Feb 12, 2026 RHT Program Touchpoint Webinar held (recording & presentation available on program page). Competitive RFPs/NOFOs will be posted as program details are finalized. Some initiatives delegated to partner agencies (OHCA, Dept of Education, Healthcare Workforce Training Commission) which may issue own procurements. State plans microgrants for local community wellness needs (no launch date yet). Co-directors: Lisa Rother (health systems) and Jackie Kanak (operations/population health). Monitor: oklahoma.gov/health/rhtp.html, Oklahoma Central Purchasing, and OHCA Procurement pages. Contact: OklahomaRHTP@health.ok.gov.
programAddress: Oklahoma State Department of Health, 123 Robert S. Kerr Ave., Suite 1702, Oklahoma City, OK 73102-6406

leadAgency: Oregon Health Authority (OHA)
notes: Oregon received $197.3M for FY2026. Feb 24, 2026 webinar at 11am PT to help organizations prepare for grant proposal process - covers program overview and RFGP application details including timeline and scope. Three funding distribution mechanisms: (1) Catalyst Awards - competitive RFGP for ready-to-implement projects across three initiatives (Healthy Communities & Prevention, Workforce Capacity & Resilience, Technology & Data Modernization); (2) Immediate Impact Awards - direct/non-competitive for state-identified opportunities; (3) Regional Sustainability Awards - subcontractors for rural health network facilitation/TA. RFGP release Spring 2026, response deadline early summer, awards mid-2026. Must serve rural (10+ miles from 40K+ population center) or frontier (6 or fewer people/sq mi). Target populations: maternal/child health, behavioral health, aging in place, chronic disease. No limits on entity types. Contact: RHTP@oha.oregon.gov or (971) 446-0946.
programAddress: Oregon Health Authority, 500 Summer Street NE, E-20, Salem, OR 97301-1097

leadAgency: Pennsylvania Department of Human Services
notes: Pennsylvania received $193.3M for FY2026. $200M/year x 5 years = $1B total. Funds flowing through eight Regional Rural Care Collaboratives (RCCs) built on existing PREP organizations, PA AHEC, University of Pittsburgh Medicaid Research Center, and other partners. PA has statutory authority via Act 45 of 2025 (Article II-H) establishing the program within DHS. February 2026 update presentation published on program page (2026-02-06). Six priority areas: technology/telehealth, workforce, maternal health, behavioral health, older adults, emergency services/transportation. No specific downstream RFA or vendor application posted yet. Monitor DHS program page for updates.
programAddress: Pennsylvania Department of Human Services, P.O. Box 2675, Harrisburg, PA 17105-2675

leadAgency: Rhode Island Department of Health (RIDOH) / EOHHS
notes: Rhode Island received $156.2M for FY2026. Interest form available to join listserv. EOHHS Rural Health Transformation Grant Initiative page (eohhs.ri.gov/initiatives/rural-health-transformation-grant) has application documents but no downstream vendor RFA/RFP yet. Five strategic goals: Making Rural America Healthy Again, Sustainable Access, Workforce Development, Innovative Care, Tech Innovation. Eligible rural areas: New Shoreham (Block Island), Westerly, and 18 state-defined rural towns. Contact: RIDOH.OPCRH@health.ri.gov. Monitor EOHHS page for downstream opportunity announcements.
programName: Rhode Island Rural Health Transformation Program
programAddress: Rhode Island Department of Health, 3 Capitol Hill, Providence, RI 02908

leadAgency: South Carolina Department of Health and Human Services
notes: South Carolina received $200.0M for FY2026. Dedicated RHTP page: scdhhs.gov/rhtp (contains application materials, webinar recordings and slides from Sept and Nov 2025 webinars). Five major initiatives: improving chronic disease outcomes, maternal health, 'Connections to Care' digital infrastructure (EHR, RPM, telehealth, statewide resource database), Tech Catalyst Fund for rural health technology startups, workforce development. SCDHHS will announce funding opportunities via Medicaid bulletins - providers should sign up on SCDHHS website. No downstream RFA, RFP, or subgrant application has been posted yet. Contact: grants@scdhhs.gov or info@scdhhs.gov.
programName: South Carolina Rural Health Transformation Program
programAddress: South Carolina Department of Health and Human Services, P.O. Box 8206, Columbia, SC 29202-8206

leadAgency: South Dakota Department of Health
notes: South Dakota received $189.5M for FY2026. Governor Rhoden signed HB 1044 into law on Jan 29, 2026 (first bill of the session), granting full spending authority for RHTP. Legislative hurdle now cleared. Informational webinar scheduled Feb 19, 2026 at 11:00 AM CT - will cover 'each initiative and the process to apply for funding.' Dedicated domain: ruralhealthtransformation.sd.gov (redirects to DOH program page). Ten strategic initiative areas with one-pagers available: technology/data, workforce, CHW expansion, Medicaid payment models (Primary Accountable Care Transformation), Rural Health Access & Quality Grants, maternal/infant health hubs, EMS enhancement, behavioral health clinic certification. Notice of Funding Opportunity, Project Narrative, Project Summary, and timeline PDFs all available on program page. Contact: DOH.info@state.sd.us or (605) 773-3361.
programName: South Dakota Rural Health Transformation Project
programAddress: South Dakota Department of Health, 600 East Capitol Avenue, Pierre, SD 57501-2536

leadAgency: Tennessee Department of Health
notes: Tennessee received $206.9M for FY2026 ($1B over 5 years). Joint Ways and Means Committee voted unanimously Jan 14, 2026 to accept federal funds. Program page now states: 'Check this Page in the Upcoming Weeks for Information on Competitive Opportunities.' Existing Healthcare Resiliency Program (HRP) at tn.gov/health/hrp.html awards competitive grants for Capital Investments and Practice Transformation - likely model for RHTP distribution. Legislation being introduced in 2026 to eliminate certificate of need and enable full scope of practice (prerequisites tied to RHTP funding). Contact: Rural.Health@tn.gov. Monitor TN DOH rural health page and Central Procurement Office.
programAddress: Tennessee Department of Health, 710 James Robertson Parkway, Nashville, TN 37243

leadAgency: Texas Health and Human Services Commission (HHSC)
notes: Texas received $281.3M for FY2026, the LARGEST state award ($1.4B over 5 years). 'Rural Texas Strong' six-part strategy. IMPORTANT: HHSC 'is not meeting with potential vendors or applicants to maintain fairness for all parties' - formal quiet period in effect. Budget Period 1 revised documents (Budget Narrative, Project Narrative, Org Chart) submitted to CMS January 30, 2026. Six initiatives with specific procurement types: (1) Make Rural Texans Healthy Again - direct awards to rural hospital districts; (2) Rural Texas Patients in Driver's Seat - RFP for 2+ clinically integrated networks/ACOs (60%+ rural members); (3) Lone Star Advanced AI & Telehealth - RFP for 2+ clinically integrated networks/ACOs; (4) Next Generation Small Town Doctor - RFA for rural healthcare providers (at least 1 award per rural county); (5) Unified Care Infrastructure & Cyber - RFO for TX DIR-listed Managed Security Providers; (6) Infrastructure & Capital Improvement - RFA for rural hospitals, clinics, behavioral health, EMS, pharmacies. Community-driven wellness solutions can begin right away; contract solicitations for Y2 funding being developed simultaneously. Subscribe via GovDelivery or monitor Electronic State Business Daily (ESBD). Contact: RuralTexasStrong@hhs.texas.gov.
programName: Rural Texas Strong: Supporting Health and Wellness
programAddress: Texas Health and Human Services Commission, 4601 W. Guadalupe St., Austin, TX 78751

leadAgency: Utah Department of Health and Human Services
notes: Utah received $195.7M for FY2026 ($1B over 5 years). DHHS previously stated plans to issue multiple RFPs 'as early as January 2026' with short submission timelines - this target has slipped. RFIs may also be issued as precursors to formal RFPs. Program page still reads 'actively preparing in anticipation of the Notice of Award' despite award being confirmed Dec 29, 2025. Seven outcome-driven initiatives with itemized budgets in transformation plan. RFPs could appear any week - short turnaround expected when they drop. Contact: ruralhealth@utah.gov.
programAddress: Utah Department of Health and Human Services, 195 North 1950 West, Salt Lake City, UT 84116

leadAgency: Vermont Agency of Human Services
notes: Vermont received $195.1M for FY2026 (among highest per-capita awards). AHS announced it will 'roll out RFPs and procurement options, some as grants and some as contracts.' Plans to post full application and summary on website, set up listserv, and conduct listening webinars for prospective applicants. Chittenden County classified as non-rural for grant purposes; providers from non-rural counties may apply for projects demonstrably impacting rural communities. Compressed spending window - must spend by September with reporting 60 days before year-end, creating urgency for rapid procurement. Award is 1 year at a time - second-year funding not guaranteed. Jan 8, 2026 presentation to House Appropriations available. Revised budget submitted to CMS by Jan 30. Monitor AHS website, DVHA RFP page (dvha.vermont.gov/administration/requests-proposals), and sign up for forthcoming listserv.
programAddress: Vermont Agency of Human Services, 280 State Drive, Center Building, Waterbury, VT 05671-1080

leadAgency: Virginia Department of Medical Assistance Services (DMAS)
notes: Virginia received $189.5M for FY2026 under 'VA Rural Vitality' initiative. DMAS aims to hire core team staff in early 2026. Implementation support contractors will help launch 'ready-to-launch programs' first. Four initiatives: CareIQ, Homegrown Health Heroes, Connected Care Closer to Home, Live Well Together. Virginia Center for Health Innovation (VCHI) leading independent evaluation. Monitor: DMAS procurement and Virginia Business Opportunities (eVA) portal.
programAddress: Department of Medical Assistance Services, 600 East Broad Street, Suite 1300, Richmond, VA 23219

leadAgency: Washington State Health Care Authority
notes: Washington received $181.3M for FY2026. IMPORTANT: Washington's expected timeline shows CMS approval and funding notification July-September 2026, with first round of funds distributed October 1, 2026 - substantially behind other states. Investment areas: hospital infrastructure, technology, maternal health, new facilities, healthcare workforce housing. Tribal consultation conducted (Dear Tribal Leader Letter Sept 2025). Monitor: HCA program page for announcements.
programAddress: Washington State Health Care Authority, 626 8th Avenue SE, Olympia, WA 98501

leadAgency: West Virginia Department of Health
notes: West Virginia received $199.5M for FY2026 (nearly double guaranteed minimum). WV Department of Health appointed Carrie Jeffries (DNP, MPH) and Dr. Soumya Prasad (pediatrician, 20+ years healthcare leadership) as RHTP program co-leads on Feb 13, 2026. DOH actively hiring seven Program Managers for each flagship initiative: Connected Care Grid, Rural Health Link, Mountain State Care Force, Health to Prosperity Pipeline, Personal Health Accelerator, HealthTech Appalachia, Smart Care Catalyst. House of Delegates passed bills (as of Feb 3, 2026) to streamline fund deployment. New DOH program page: health.wv.gov/rural-health-transformation-program. Funds awarded based on need and readiness with emphasis on measurable outcomes. Contact: RHTP@wv.gov.
programName: West Virginia Rural Health Transformation Program
programAddress: Office of the Governor, State Capitol, 1900 Kanawha Blvd. E, Charleston, WV 25305

leadAgency: Wisconsin Department of Health Services (DHS)
notes: Wisconsin received $203.7M for FY2026. RHTP Advisory Council application open through February 27, 2026 (survey.alchemer.com/s3/8621599/DRAFT-RHTP-Advisory-Council-Application) - advisory role, not funding. DHS Office of Grants Management (OGM) will lead implementation and oversight. DHS still recruiting internal management team. 2026 funds distributed in early January, may be spent through Sept 30, 2027. Three initiatives: workforce, technology/innovation, care transformation through partnerships. Plans include competitive grants for innovative workforce projects, closed-loop referral systems, telehealth, multi-sector partnership grants. No RHTP-related solicitations yet on DHS Current Grant Funding Opportunities page. Procurement contact: DHSProcurement@dhs.wisconsin.gov. Subscribe for updates: public.govdelivery.com/accounts/WIDHS/subscriber/new?topic_id=WIDHS_75.
programName: Building a Healthier Future for Rural Wisconsin
programAddress: Wisconsin Department of Health Services, 1 W. Wilson St., Madison, WI 53703

leadAgency: Wyoming Department of Health
notes: Wyoming received $205.0M for FY2026 ($5M more than requested, second-largest per-capita award behind Alaska). HB 122 passed House Appropriations Committee unanimously (7-0) and advanced to House floor as of mid-February 2026. Legislature budget session commenced Feb 9. Program page timeline confirms: March-April 2026 RFAs and RFPs posted with informational webinars and Q&A sessions prior to posting; May-June 2026 awards made and funds drawn down; July-August 2026 contracts executed. Document Library on Google Drive contains Notice of Award and final application. 80% of first-year funds go to perpetuity fund for long-term sustainability; remaining funds for time-limited initiatives. Key elements: CAH Basic incentive program, EMS consolidation grants, medical education pipeline with 5-year service commitments. Contact: monitor health.wyo.gov RHTP page.
programAddress: Wyoming Department of Health, 2300 Capitol Ave, Cheyenne, WY 82002
